text.p: These are the highlights of the main Sao Paulo and Rio de Janeiro newspapers this morning.
GAZETA MERCANTIL
-- CURRENT ACCOUNT DEFICIT WORRIES INVESTORS

Brazil's current account deficit could exceed $30 billion in 1997, according to analysts who say the government may have to introduce monetary restrictions or limit imports by the middle of this year if it does not act now to contain the deficit.
-- REQUIAO SUGGESTS CENBANK INTERNAL AUDIT

Senator Roberto Requiao, the head of a special Parliamentary Investigative Committee (CPI) probing a multi-million-dollar scam involving state and municipal bonds, wants the Central Bank to conduct an internal audit in connection with the inquiry.
-- INVESTMENT FUNDS THRIVE ON PRIVATIZATION
Funds specializing in investing in companies which are being privatized are mushrooming in recent months as Brazil continues its privatization drive.
FOLHA DE SAO PAULO
-- SAO PAULO VIOLENCE IS THE WORST IN EIGHT MONTHS
The past weekend has been the most violent in Sao Paulo in the past eight months with 57 murders between Friday evening and Monday morning.
-- EX-OFFICIAL TO ACCUSE SAO PAULO MAYOR PITTA
A former Sao Paulo city official is expected to implicate the current mayor of Sao Paulo, Celso Pitta, in a multi-million-dollar scam involving state and municipal bonds.
JORNAL DO BRASIL
-- STRIKE LEAVES RIO WITHOUT BUSES
Rio de Janeiro bus companies have gone on a 24-hour strike to press for an increase in bus fares, leaving the city virtually without public transport.
-- UNEMPLOYMENT RISES AMONG PEOPLE WITH LITTLE EDUCATION

People with little education are most affected by unemployment, according to a study by the IBGE which shows that the number of people employed without any formal education has fallen 10.9 percent between 1995 and 1996.
-- PERNAMBUCO JAIL REBELLION LEAVES SIX DEAD
A jail rebellion in Recife, Pernambuco state, has ended with six people dead.
-- Reuters has not verified the stories and cannot vouch for their accuracy.
((--Simona de Logu, Rio de Janeiro newsroom 5521 5074151))
